paper_id: Impact of potassium management on soil dynamics and crop uptake in rice systems

high_priority_corrections.recommended_action: Remove these inferred methods from the 'analytical_methods.measurement_protocols' section.

paper_metadata.title: Impact of potassium management on soil dynamics and crop uptake in rice systems
paper_metadata.primary_focus: Potassium management, soil K dynamics, crop K uptake, rice systems

research_methodology.experimental_design: Randomized block design (RBD) with three replications and nine treatments.

temporal_scope.data_collection_frequency: Multiple times per season (beginning, mid-season, after harvest for soil; maximum tillering, panicle initiation, harvest for plant)

spatial_scope.regional_representativeness: Representative for India and similar agroecological contexts

controls_and_treatments: T5: 20 kg K₂O ha⁻¹ + straw (3 t ha⁻¹)
T6: 30 kg K₂O ha⁻¹ + straw (3 t ha⁻¹)
T7: 40 kg K₂O ha⁻¹ + straw (3 t ha⁻¹)
T9: 40 kg K₂O ha⁻¹ + 1% KNO₃ foliar spray at panicle initiation stage

measurement_protocols: Exchangeable potassium: Ammonium acetate method (Hanway and Heidel, 1952)
Reserve potassium: Nitric acid extraction (Wood and De Turk, 1941)
Soil nitrogen: Alkaline KMnO4 (Subbiah and Asija, 1956)
Soil phosphorus: Sodium bicarbonate extraction method (Page, 1982)

analysis_methods: Statistical procedures followed Gomez and Gomez (1984) and Panse and Sukhatme (1961)
statistical_approach.significance_testing: Least significant difference (LSD) at a 0.05 probability level
statistical_approach.uncertainty_quantification: LSD (0.05) values reported for grain yield

primary_measurements.measurement_context: Dry and Wet seasons, rice–rice cropping system. LSD (0.05) = 0.6 t ha⁻¹ for both seasons.
Dry and Wet seasons. Values represent K removed by crop, derived from Table 2.
Dry and Wet seasons, Maximum Tillering (MT) stage. Values are examples from the text, representing ranges observed.
Dry and Wet seasons, Maximum Tillering (MT) stage. Values are examples from the text, representing ranges observed.
Dry and Wet seasons, Maximum Tillering (MT) stage. Values are examples from the text, representing ranges observed.
Annual total K balance across dry and wet seasons, derived from Table 2.

temporal_patterns.trend_description: Lower total K uptake in DS than WS. Different partitioning across growth stages.
temporal_patterns.seasonal_component: DS: 12–13% by MT, 23–27% between MT and PI, 59–64% between PI and maturity. WS: 16–18% by MT, 38–44% between MT and PI, 40–44% between PI and maturity.

temporal_patterns.trend_description: Generally higher in DS compared to WS. Decline from MT to PI stage in surface soil.
temporal_patterns.seasonal_component: Higher K release from soil reserves in DS, possibly due to soil drying and reduced leaching.

temporal_patterns.trend_description: Conversion to exchangeable forms evident in DS (declined at harvest). Higher levels in WS at harvest.
temporal_patterns.seasonal_component: Higher K retention in WS due to higher soil moisture levels.

temporal_patterns.trend_description: Declined from MT to PI, followed by an increase at harvest. Consistently higher in DS compared to WS.
temporal_patterns.seasonal_component: Mobilization during critical growth stages, replenishment through root turnover and microbial activity. Higher levels in WS may reflect enhanced mineral weathering and nutrient cycling.

comparative_results.practical_significance: T9 significantly higher yield (3.8 t ha⁻¹ DS, 5.4 t ha⁻¹ WS) compared to T1 (2.7 t ha⁻¹ DS, 4.2 t ha⁻¹ WS). T3, T4, T6 at par with T9 in DS. T4, T6, T7 at par with T9 in WS.
Attributed to differences in climatic conditions and water availability, enhancing nutrient uptake efficiency during WS.
Treatments with straw (T5, T6, T7, T8) exhibited positive K balances (e.g., T7: 89 kg ha⁻¹), while chemical fertilizers alone (T1-T4, T9) showed negative balances (e.g., T9: -140 kg ha⁻¹).

regions: Eastern and South-Eastern Coastal Plain agroclimatic zone
geographic_details.landscape_position: Lowland (implied by puddled rice and shallow water table)

soil_properties.soil_classification: Not explicitly classified, but described as sandy loam

chemical_properties.non_exchangeable_and_reserve_potassium_d: Corresponding increases in non-exchangeable and reserve potassium at 15–30- and 30–45-cm depths (values not specified)

physical_properties.drainage: Poorly drained during rainy season, moderately well drained during summer

land_use_context.historical_context: Intensified nutrient depletion due to high-yielding rice varieties during the Green Revolution
sustainability_metrics: Soil health (implied by K dynamics and organic matter)

rates.nitrogen: 80 kg N ha⁻¹ (30 kg N ha⁻¹ basal + 50 kg N ha⁻¹ in two splits)
rates.straw_K_contribution: ~45 kg K ha⁻¹ (from 3 t ha⁻¹ straw)

other_practices.tillage: Puddling, power tiller for straw incorporation, second plowing after 15 days for decomposition
other_practices.pest_management: SAAF (2 g L⁻¹), streptocycline (0.15 g L⁻¹), Furadan (10 kg acre⁻¹)

data_collection_schedule: Soil samples: beginning of experiment, 30 DAT, 60 DAT, after harvest
Plant samples: maximum tillering, panicle initiation, harvest stages

seasonal_variations.seasonal_pattern: Lower in dry season, higher in wet season. Different partitioning across growth stages.
Generally higher in dry season compared to wet season. Declines from MT to PI in surface soil.
Declined at harvest in dry season, higher levels in wet season at harvest.
Declined from MT to PI, followed by an increase at harvest. Higher in wet season than dry season.

long_term_trends.trend_direction: Negative balance with chemical fertilizers alone
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Risk of soil K depletion under intensive farming without organic amendments.

methodological_strengths: Comprehensive analysis of different soil K forms (exchangeable, non-exchangeable, reserve)
Evaluation across two distinct cropping seasons (dry and wet)
Integration of inorganic and organic K sources
Detailed measurement protocols for soil analysis
methodological_limitations: Study conducted at a single site, limiting spatial generalizability
Short-term study (one full year cycle), not assessing long-term cumulative effects
Lack of explicit analytical precision or detection limits for all measurements
No explicit mention of statistical power for all analyses
Plant analysis methods not fully described in provided text snippet.
data_quality_assessment.data_completeness: High for reported parameters and experimental design.

representativeness.spatial_representativeness: Limited to the specific agroclimatic zone of Odisha, India. Extrapolation to other regions should be cautious.
representativeness.temporal_representativeness: Covers a full annual cycle of rice-rice system, but inter-annual variability is not assessed.
representativeness.system_representativeness: Representative for puddled, transplanted rice–rice systems under intensive farming.

uncertainty_sources: Potential for unmeasured environmental factors influencing K dynamics

key_methodological_references: Hanway and Heidel (1952) for exchangeable K
Wood and De Turk (1941) for reserve K
Subbiah and Asija (1956) for soil N
Gomez and Gomez (1984) for statistical procedures
Panse and Sukhatme (1961) for statistical methods
Gopinath et al. (2020) for GRAPES software
comparative_studies: Kumar et al. (2018) on integrated nutrient management and K transformation
Kumbhar and Sonar (1979) and Kalita (2020) on K uptake patterns
Lalitha and Dhakshinamoorthy (2014) on forms of soil K
Saha et al. (2009) on straw contribution to K supply
Thanh et al. (2016) on straw improving soil properties
Wihardjaka et al. (2022) on fertilizer management and K dynamics
Venkateshwarlu et al. (2014) on fertilizer and organic manure effects on K dynamics
Witt et al. (1999) and Wang et al. (2023) on combined fertilizers and straw for soil health
Wihardjaka et al. (1999) and Balik et al. (2019) on K balances and organic amendments
Chivenge et al. (2020) on straw incorporation and nutrient cycling
Schmidt et al. (2015) on straw and biodiversity for nutrient cycling
Adhikari et al. (2019) on foliar K application
literature_integration.theoretical_framework: Potassium's role as an essential macronutrient, K depletion in intensive rice farming, dynamic equilibrium between different soil K forms, importance of integrated nutrient management for sustainable rice production.
benchmarking_data: Recommended K₂O dose for wetland rice in India (40–60 kg ha⁻¹)
Estimated K removal by rice (15 kg N, 4 kg P₂O₅, 24 kg K₂O per ton grain)

extraction_metadata.data_richness_assessment: The paper is rich in experimental details, quantitative findings on K dynamics and yield, and discussion of implications. Less detailed on long-term trends or specific analytical precision metrics.
potential_ambiguities: Exact study duration in years is not explicitly stated, but inferred as at least one full year covering both seasons.
extraction_limitations: Specific analytical precision/detection limits for all measurements were not provided in the text.
Detailed climate data beyond averages (e.g., daily/monthly patterns) were not available.
Long-term data and inter-annual variability were not part of this study's scope.
recommended_validation_checks: Verify all numerical values and units against the original paper's tables and text.
Confirm the interpretation of statistical significance and relationships.

corrections_applied: Corrected and completed 'Total K uptake at harvest' data from Table 2.
Removed inferred plant analysis methods from 'analytical_methods.measurement_protocols' as they were not in the provided text.
enhancements_added: Added initial soil exchangeable potassium values for 15-30 cm and 30-45 cm depths.
Added specific statistical references (Gomez and Gomez, Panse and Sukhatme, Gopinath et al.) to 'statistical_approach.analysis_methods' and 'literature_integration.key_methodological_references'.
Clarified 'sample_size' for grain yield as '3 replications'.
areas_enriched: Quantitative findings (K uptake, initial soil K)
enhancement_summary.enhancement_justification: Enhancements were made to improve numerical accuracy, ensure fidelity to the provided source text, provide more complete contextual and methodological details, and enrich the quantitative findings for a more comprehensive and scientifically precise extraction.

validation_quality.validator_notes: Stage 1A extraction contained significant omissions in quantitative data (full K uptake table) and included inferred methodological details (plant analysis methods) not present in the provided source text. Several minor contextual and literature integration details were also missing. The enhanced extraction addresses these issues comprehensively, significantly improving accuracy and completeness.
recommended_next_steps: Ensure all extracted information is directly verifiable from the provided source text.
Prioritize complete extraction of all tabular quantitative data.
Review for any inferred information that is not explicitly stated in the source.

results.paper_id: Impact of potassium management on soil dynamics and crop uptake in rice systems
